description: The 28-year-old supermodel showed off her runway strut as she crossed a street in Manhattan with her eyes covered with white framed cat-eye sunglasses.
title: Elsa Hosk steps out in Harley Davidson sweater in New York
title_page: Elsa Hosk steps out in Harley Davidson sweater in New York | Daily Mail Online
text:
Elsa Hosk showed her flair for fashion on Thursday as she strolled through New York City.
The blonde beauty had a biker chic moment as she teamed a Harley-Davidson sweater with slim fit black jeans.
The 28-year-old supermodel showed off her runway strut as she crossed a street in Manhattan with her eyes covered with white framed cat-eye sunglasses.
Big Apple babe: Elsa Hosk stepped out looking ultra cool in New York Harley on Thursday
Elsa, who hails from Sweden, wore her long blonde locks up in a playful ponytail and toted a tan shoulder bag.
Over the weekend the 5ft 10in beauty walked for Balmain during Paris Fashion Week.
She sashayed down the catwalk in a sheer tunic and black pants with super dramatic eye makeup.
Supermodel strut: The Victoria's Secret stunner sported a Harley Davidson sweater and cat-eye sunglasses
The 28-year-old beauty carried a stylish tan shoulder bag and swept her long locks up in a playful ponytail
Elsa also walked at this year's New York Fashion Week and has modeled for high-end fashion houses like Dior and Ungaro.
Her career saw a huge boost in 2015 when she was promoted to Angel status by Victoria's Secret, joining an elite group of famed supermodels that include Alessandra Ambrosio, Jasmine Tookes, Behati Prinsloo and Stella Maxwell.
However, the coveted gig has increased the pressure to keep her model figure in tip top shape.
Blonde beauty: The catwalk stunner was spotted out in New York earlier in the week wearing a stylish coat
Elsa, who took up basketball at the age of seven and considered becoming a professional player, told Sports Illustrated that playing the sport helps her with modelling.
'It just makes you a better model if you're athletic, I think,' she explained.
'Even holding a pose for a long time, making your body into strange shapes, and just knowing what it looks like - I think [for me] that comes from being a basketball player.'
